title: Proverbs Chapter 6 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Proverbs chapter 6 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Proverbs Chapter 6 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Proverbs Chapter 6.

questions.question: According to Proverbs 6:6, what should a sluggard consider to be wise?
questions.correctAnswer: The ways of the ant
questions.explanation: Proverbs 6:6 states, 'Go to the ant, thou sluggard; consider her ways, and be wise,' encouraging learning from the ant's diligence.

questions.question: What does Proverbs 6:17 list as one of the things the LORD hates?
questions.correctAnswer: A lying tongue
questions.explanation: Proverbs 6:17 includes 'a lying tongue' among the six things the LORD hates.

questions.question: What is described as a lamp and light in Proverbs 6:23?
questions.correctAnswer: The commandment and the law
questions.explanation: Proverbs 6:23 says, 'For the commandment is a lamp; and the law is light,' illustrating their guiding role.

questions.question: What will come like one that travelleth according to Proverbs 6:11?
questions.correctAnswer: Poverty
questions.explanation: Proverbs 6:11 warns that poverty will come as one that travels, emphasizing consequences of sloth.

questions.question: Who is instructed to keep their father's commandment in Proverbs 6:20?
questions.correctAnswer: My son
questions.explanation: Proverbs 6:20 states, 'My son, keep thy father's commandment,' directly addressing the son.

questions.question: According to Proverbs 6:31, what must a thief do if found after stealing?
questions.correctAnswer: Restore sevenfold
questions.explanation: Proverbs 6:31 instructs that if a thief is found, he must restore sevenfold.

questions.question: What does Proverbs 6:28 compare going upon hot coals to?
questions.correctAnswer: Being burned
questions.explanation: Proverbs 6:28 asks if one can walk on hot coals and not be burned, implying it is impossible.

questions.question: According to Proverbs 6:25, what should you not lust after in your heart?
questions.correctAnswer: Her beauty
questions.explanation: Proverbs 6:25 warns, 'Lust not after her beauty in thine heart.'

questions.question: What does Proverbs 6:13 say a wicked man does with his fingers?
questions.correctAnswer: He teacheth with his fingers
questions.explanation: Proverbs 6:13 states, 'He teacheth with his fingers,' referring to the wicked man's deceitful behavior.

questions.question: What does Proverbs 6:3 advise you to do when you are in the hand of your friend?
options: Go, humble thyself, and make sure thy friend
questions.correctAnswer: Go, humble thyself, and make sure thy friend
questions.explanation: Proverbs 6:3 advises humility and making peace with your friend to deliver yourself.

questions.question: True or False: Proverbs 6:19 states that a false witness that speaketh lies is one of the things the LORD hates.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Proverbs 6:19 specifically lists 'a false witness that speaketh lies' as an abomination to the LORD.

questions.question: True or False: Proverbs 6:9 encourages continued sleep and rest for the sluggard.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Proverbs 6:9 questions 'How long wilt thou sleep, O sluggard?' urging the sluggard to arise and not continue sleeping.

questions.question: True or False: Proverbs 6:22 says the law will talk with you when you awaken.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Proverbs 6:22 states that the law 'shall talk with thee' when you awaken.

questions.question: Complete this verse from Proverbs 6:5: 'Deliver thyself as a ____ from the hand of the hunter, and as a bird from the hand of the fowler.'
questions.correctAnswer: roe
questions.explanation: Proverbs 6:5 uses the simile 'Deliver thyself as a roe from the hand of the hunter,' illustrating swift escape.

questions.question: Complete this verse from Proverbs 6:24: 'To keep thee from the evil woman, from the flattery of the tongue of a ____ woman.'
questions.correctAnswer: strange
questions.explanation: Proverbs 6:24 warns against the flattery of the tongue of a strange woman.

medium.title: Proverbs Chapter 6 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Proverbs Chapter 6 to real-life situations.

questions.question: A fellow believer is worried about being financially responsible for a friend's debt. Based on Proverbs 6, what biblical principle would you share about this situation?
options: Avoid being surety for others to prevent personal ruin
Always guarantee your friend's debts to show loyalty
Ignore debts as they will resolve themselves
Borrow more to cover your friend's obligations
questions.correctAnswer: Avoid being surety for others to prevent personal ruin
questions.explanation: Proverbs 6:1-3 warns against becoming surety for a friend or stranger, as it can lead to being trapped by your own words. It advises humbling yourself and securing your friend quickly to avoid loss.

questions.question: How does Proverbs 6 teach about diligence and work ethic using an example from nature?
options: By observing the ant's preparation and hard work
By watching the lazy bird that waits for food
By relying on chance and luck like wild animals
By following the ways of the sluggard
questions.correctAnswer: By observing the ant's preparation and hard work
questions.explanation: Verses 6-8 instruct us to consider the ways of the ant, which works without a guide and stores food in summer and harvest, illustrating wisdom in diligence and planning.

questions.question: What warning does Proverbs 6 give about the consequences of laziness?
options: Poverty and want will come suddenly like an armed man
Laziness leads to wealth and honor
Sleep a little more to gain strength
questions.correctAnswer: Poverty and want will come suddenly like an armed man
questions.explanation: Verses 9-11 describe how a little sleep and slumber lead to poverty arriving unexpectedly and need coming as an armed man, warning against laziness.

questions.question: According to Proverbs 6, what characterizes a wicked person who causes harm to others?
options: A froward mouth, winking eyes, and fingers teaching mischief
One who works diligently and helps others
questions.correctAnswer: A froward mouth, winking eyes, and fingers teaching mischief
questions.explanation: Verses 12-14 depict a wicked person with deceptive gestures and continual mischief, sowing discord and inviting sudden calamity.

questions.question: What are some things the LORD hates according to Proverbs 6, and what does this teach about integrity?
options: Pride, lying, shedding innocent blood, wicked plans, swift feet to mischief, false witness, and sowing discord
questions.correctAnswer: Pride, lying, shedding innocent blood, wicked plans, swift feet to mischief, false witness, and sowing discord
questions.explanation: Verses 16-19 list seven abominations to the LORD, emphasizing the importance of humility, honesty, peace, and avoiding harmful behavior.

questions.question: How does Proverbs 6 encourage children to regard their parents' teachings?
options: Bind them on their heart and neck, so they guide them at all times
Forget them once they grow older
Question and reject them if inconvenient
Only follow them when others are watching
questions.correctAnswer: Bind them on their heart and neck, so they guide them at all times
questions.explanation: Verses 20-22 instruct children to keep their parents' commands close to their heart and always remember them for guidance in life.

questions.question: What is described as a lamp and light in Proverbs 6, and how does this relate to Christian living?
options: The commandment and the law, which provide guidance and life
questions.correctAnswer: The commandment and the law, which provide guidance and life
questions.explanation: Verse 23 explains that God's commandments and law are like a lamp and light, providing instruction and a path to life, highlighting the importance of obedience.

questions.question: A believer is tempted by an adulterous woman. Based on Proverbs 6, what biblical truth helps resist this temptation?
options: Lust not after her beauty or be taken by her eyelids
Give in to temptation to satisfy desires
Trust that no harm will come from it
questions.correctAnswer: Lust not after her beauty or be taken by her eyelids
questions.explanation: Verses 24-25 warn against lusting after the strange woman and being captivated by her looks, teaching the need for self-control to avoid ruin.

questions.question: What does Proverbs 6 say about the consequences of adultery?
options: It destroys the adulterer's own soul and brings dishonor and lasting reproach
It is a private matter with no impact
questions.correctAnswer: It destroys the adulterer's own soul and brings dishonor and lasting reproach
questions.explanation: Verses 32-33 explain that adultery shows a lack of understanding, destroys the soul, and results in wounds and dishonor that cannot be erased.

questions.question: True or False: Proverbs 6 teaches that jealousy is a mild emotion easily overcome.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Verse 34 describes jealousy as the rage of a man, implying it is a strong and dangerous emotion that leads to fierce vengeance.

questions.question: True or False: According to Proverbs 6, a thief who steals out of hunger is fully forgiven without repayment.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Verses 30-31 clarify that even if a thief steals due to hunger, he must restore sevenfold, emphasizing accountability and restitution.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Proverbs 6 describes the commandment as a ______, and the law as ______.
questions.correctAnswer: lamp; light
questions.explanation: Verse 23 calls the commandment a lamp and the law light, symbolizing guidance and clarity for the believer's life.

questions.question: A believer desires to avoid quarrels and strife in the church. What teaching from Proverbs 6 applies to maintaining peace among brethren?
options: Avoid sowing discord as it is an abomination to the LORD
Encourage division to protect personal interests
Ignore conflicts as they resolve themselves
questions.correctAnswer: Avoid sowing discord as it is an abomination to the LORD
questions.explanation: Verse 19 lists sowing discord among brethren as one of the things the LORD hates, encouraging believers to pursue peace and unity.

questions.question: What practical advice does Proverbs 6 give about waking from laziness and starting work?
options: Do not give sleep to your eyes or slumber to your eyelids; deliver yourself like a roe or bird
Sleep as much as needed before working
Wait for others to start before you begin
questions.correctAnswer: Do not give sleep to your eyes or slumber to your eyelids; deliver yourself like a roe or bird
questions.explanation: Verses 4-5 urge rising from laziness quickly and escaping danger as a roe from the hunter or a bird from the fowler, symbolizing urgency and diligence.

questions.question: How does Proverbs 6 describe the behavior of someone who is deceitful and manipulative?
options: They wink with eyes, speak with feet, and teach with fingers
questions.correctAnswer: They wink with eyes, speak with feet, and teach with fingers
questions.explanation: Verse 13 characterizes the deceitful man as one who uses subtle gestures and manipulation, indicating hidden mischief.

hard.title: Proverbs Chapter 6 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Proverbs Chapter 6.

questions.question: In Proverbs 6:6-8, the ant is used as an example for what kind of behavior?
questions.correctAnswer: Diligence and foresight
questions.explanation: Proverbs 6:6-8 illustrates the ant's behavior as one without a guide who prepares its food in summer and harvest, teaching the value of diligence and foresight.

questions.question: What literary device is prominently used in Proverbs 6:27-28 when comparing sin to taking fire into one's bosom or walking on hot coals?
questions.correctAnswer: Simile
questions.explanation: Verses 27-28 use similes comparing sin with fire and hot coals to emphasize inevitable consequences, a common Hebrew poetic device.

questions.question: According to Proverbs 6:16-19, which of the following is NOT listed among the seven things the LORD hates?
options: A false witness that speaketh lies
questions.correctAnswer: A proud heart
questions.explanation: Proverbs 6:17 lists 'a proud look' but not specifically a 'proud heart,' which shows the focus on outward arrogance rather than internal pride.

questions.question: The admonition in Proverbs 6:20-23 to bind commandments upon the heart and neck functions as a metaphor for what ancient Israelite practice?
questions.correctAnswer: Wearing phylacteries (tefillin)
questions.explanation: Binding commandments on the heart and neck alludes to the ancient practice of wearing tefillin as a physical reminder to keep God's law (Deuteronomy 6:8).

questions.question: In the context of Proverbs 6, what is the primary warning associated with suretyship mentioned in verses 1-5?
questions.correctAnswer: The danger of financial entrapment
questions.explanation: Verses 1-5 warn about the peril of becoming surety for another’s debt, emphasizing the risk of being trapped by one's own words and urging quick action to avoid ruin.

questions.question: How does Proverbs 6:11 use the imagery of a traveler and an armed man to describe the arrival of poverty?
questions.correctAnswer: Sudden and inevitable
questions.explanation: The verse depicts poverty coming unexpectedly like a traveler and want as an armed man, highlighting sudden and unavoidable consequences of slothfulness.

questions.question: Which theme in Proverbs 6:12-15 reflects a recurring biblical warning against false speech and deceit?
options: The characterization of a wicked person by his froward mouth
questions.correctAnswer: The characterization of a wicked person by his froward mouth
questions.explanation: Verses 12-15 describe a deceitful man whose speech and gestures sow discord, echoing the biblical theme condemning false speech.

questions.question: True or False: Proverbs 6:30-31 distinguishes between stealing out of necessity and stealing out of greed, prescribing restoration sevenfold for the former.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: These verses acknowledge the thief who steals to satisfy hunger but require full restitution if caught, highlighting justice tempered with understanding.

questions.question: In Proverbs 6:32-35, what is the consequence of adultery as described in these verses?
options: Loss of understanding, soul destruction, and lasting dishonor
questions.correctAnswer: Loss of understanding, soul destruction, and lasting dishonor
questions.explanation: The passage explains that adultery leads to the destruction of one’s soul, dishonor, and an unremovable reproach, emphasizing severe moral consequences.

questions.question: How does the structure of Proverbs 6:16-19 reflect a common Hebrew poetic device?
options: Numerical parallelism (list of six and seven)
questions.correctAnswer: Numerical parallelism (list of six and seven)
questions.explanation: The passage uses numerical parallelism, listing six things the LORD hates and then seven abominations, a stylistic feature for emphasis in Hebrew poetry.

questions.question: What cultural insight about ancient Near Eastern social obligations can be drawn from the warning against becoming surety in Proverbs 6:1-5?
options: Suretyship was a serious financial and social risk
Slavery was a common penalty for debt
Hospitality was freely given without condition
questions.correctAnswer: Suretyship was a serious financial and social risk
questions.explanation: In the ancient Near East, guaranteeing a friend's debt could lead to severe financial loss and social disgrace, as reflected in these verses.

questions.question: Which New Testament teaching aligns with the warning in Proverbs 6:24-25 about guarding against the enticement of a 'strange woman'?
options: Jesus' teaching on lust in Matthew 5:28
Paul's instructions on love in 1 Corinthians 13
Peter's exhortation to holiness in 1 Peter 1
John's command to love one another in John 13
questions.correctAnswer: Jesus' teaching on lust in Matthew 5:28
questions.explanation: Jesus warns that looking at a woman lustfully is committing adultery in the heart, paralleling the Proverbs caution against lusting after a strange woman.

questions.question: What is the significance of the phrase 'a lamp' and 'light' in Proverbs 6:23 in the context of biblical symbolism?
options: It symbolizes divine guidance and moral clarity
It refers to physical illumination only
questions.correctAnswer: It symbolizes divine guidance and moral clarity
questions.explanation: Light and lamp imagery frequently symbolize God's law bringing understanding and direction, as seen here and throughout Scripture.

questions.question: According to Proverbs 6:13, the wicked man 'winketh with his eyes' and 'speaketh with his feet.' What does this suggest about his behavior in the ancient Near Eastern context?
questions.correctAnswer: Secretive and deceptive communication
questions.explanation: The gestures imply covert signals and deceit, common in ancient Near Eastern idioms describing duplicity.

questions.question: How does Proverbs 6:22-23 emphasize the role of parental instruction in the moral life of the child?
options: As temporary advice to be discarded
As burdensome rules to rebel against
questions.correctAnswer: As continual guidance and protection
questions.explanation: The verses depict commandments as leading, keeping, and talking with the child, highlighting their ongoing protective and instructive role.

theological.title: Proverbs Chapter 6 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Proverbs Chapter 6 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: What does Proverbs 6:1-3 advise regarding being surety for a friend?
options: Humble yourself and make sure your friend to avoid ruin
Ignore the pledge and trust God will provide
Demand immediate repayment from your friend
Avoid all friendships to prevent financial loss
questions.correctAnswer: Humble yourself and make sure your friend to avoid ruin
questions.explanation: Proverbs 6:1-3 teaches the wisdom of humbling oneself and securing the friend to avoid being trapped by one's own words. This aligns with biblical principles of wise stewardship and reconciliation (see also Matthew 5:25-26, Romans 13:7, Luke 14:28, Ecclesiastes 5:5).

questions.question: What lesson about diligence is drawn from the ant in Proverbs 6:6-8?
options: The ant works without a guide and prepares food in summer and harvest
The ant rests often and depends on others for food
The ant is lazy and waits for help
The ant only works when commanded by a ruler
questions.correctAnswer: The ant works without a guide and prepares food in summer and harvest
questions.explanation: Verses 6-8 commend the ant’s self-motivation and preparation, illustrating the virtue of industriousness without needing external pressure, consistent with Proverbs 10:4 and 2 Thessalonians 3:10, emphasizing work ethic and foresight.

questions.question: According to Proverbs 6:9-11, what is the consequence of excessive sleep and laziness?
options: Poverty will come like a traveler and want like an armed man
Peace and rest will be abundant
questions.correctAnswer: Poverty will come like a traveler and want like an armed man
questions.explanation: These verses warn that laziness leads to sudden poverty and need, illustrating the biblical principle that slothfulness leads to destruction (cf. Proverbs 10:4, 20:13; 2 Thessalonians 3:10).

questions.question: What behaviors characterize the 'naughty person' described in Proverbs 6:12-14?
options: Froward mouth, winking with eyes, devising mischief continually
questions.correctAnswer: Froward mouth, winking with eyes, devising mischief continually
questions.explanation: Verses 12-14 depict a wicked person who is deceitful and sows discord, reflecting the sinful nature of humanity opposed to God’s righteousness (cf. James 3:6-8; Psalm 10:7; Romans 1:29).

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT one of the six things the LORD hates as listed in Proverbs 6:16-19?
options: Feet swift in running to mischief
questions.correctAnswer: Hands that give generously
questions.explanation: Proverbs 6:16-19 lists things God hates such as pride, lying, and violence, but generosity is praised elsewhere (cf. Proverbs 3:9-10; Luke 6:38; 2 Corinthians 9:7).

questions.question: What instruction is given about parental commands and law in Proverbs 6:20-23?
options: Bind them upon your heart and neck; they guide and keep you
Forsake them when you become wise
Only follow them when others are watching
Ignore them if they seem difficult
questions.correctAnswer: Bind them upon your heart and neck; they guide and keep you
questions.explanation: These verses emphasize the importance of internalizing parental instruction as a lamp and light guiding life, consistent with Deuteronomy 6:6-7 and Psalm 119:105.

questions.question: According to Proverbs 6:24-26, what is the purpose of the commandments and law in relation to the 'strange woman'?
options: To keep you from the evil woman and her flattering tongue
To encourage you to seek her beauty
To ignore her completely without caution
To teach you how to flatter others
questions.correctAnswer: To keep you from the evil woman and her flattering tongue
questions.explanation: The law serves as protection against temptations such as adulterous women, symbolizing sin's destructive power (cf. Proverbs 5:3-6; 1 Corinthians 6:18; James 1:14-15).

questions.question: What analogy does Proverbs 6:27-29 use to describe the danger of adultery?
options: Taking fire in one's bosom and walking on hot coals without being burned
Building a house without a foundation
questions.correctAnswer: Taking fire in one's bosom and walking on hot coals without being burned
questions.explanation: These metaphors illustrate the inevitable harm of adultery, showing sin’s destructive consequences, consistent with Hosea 4:12 and 1 Corinthians 10:13.

questions.question: What is said about a man who commits adultery in Proverbs 6:32-33?
options: He lacks understanding, destroys his soul, and gains wounds and dishonor
He is praised for his courage
He is forgiven immediately without consequences
He gains wealth and honor among peers
questions.correctAnswer: He lacks understanding, destroys his soul, and gains wounds and dishonor
questions.explanation: Adultery is portrayed as foolish and self-destructive, bringing lasting shame, echoing Biblical teaching on sin’s penalty (cf. Hebrews 13:4; Galatians 6:7-8; Psalm 51:1-4).

questions.question: How does Proverbs 6:34-35 describe the reaction of a jealous man?
options: He will not spare in the day of vengeance and will not accept ransom
He will forgive quickly and forget the offense
He will seek peace and reconciliation
He will ignore the matter completely
questions.correctAnswer: He will not spare in the day of vengeance and will not accept ransom
questions.explanation: These verses warn about the severity of jealousy, which fuels unforgiving wrath, paralleling biblical warnings about anger (James 1:20; Proverbs 27:4; Romans 12:19).

questions.question: What does Proverbs 6:30-31 say about a thief who steals to satisfy hunger?
options: Men do not despise him, but if found, he must restore sevenfold
He is praised for survival skills
He is immediately forgiven without restitution
questions.correctAnswer: Men do not despise him, but if found, he must restore sevenfold
questions.explanation: This passage balances mercy for necessity with justice requiring restitution, reflecting Old Testament laws (Exodus 22:1; Luke 19:8; 2 Corinthians 8:12).

questions.question: What is the significance of the 'commandment' described as a lamp and the 'law' as light in Proverbs 6:23?
options: They provide guidance and instruction for life
They are burdens that restrict freedom
questions.correctAnswer: They provide guidance and instruction for life
questions.explanation: This metaphor emphasizes God’s word as essential for righteous living, consistent with Psalm 119:105 and John 8:12.

questions.question: According to Proverbs 6:18, what kind of heart does the LORD hate?
options: A heart that deviseth wicked imaginations
A heart full of love and mercy
A heart that trusts God fully
questions.correctAnswer: A heart that deviseth wicked imaginations
questions.explanation: God abhors wicked intentions, which contrast His holiness and justice (cf. Jeremiah 17:9; Romans 1:28; James 4:1).

questions.question: What role does the law of the father and mother play in the life of the son according to Proverbs 6:21-22?
options: It continually guides, keeps, and talks to him
It burdens him with impossible demands
It is to be set aside in adulthood
It is only for public display
questions.correctAnswer: It continually guides, keeps, and talks to him
questions.explanation: This emphasizes the formative and protective role of parental instruction consistent with Deuteronomy 6:6-7 and Ephesians 6:4.

questions.question: What is the biblical teaching on 'sowing discord among brethren' as mentioned in Proverbs 6:19?
options: It is an abomination to the LORD
questions.correctAnswer: It is an abomination to the LORD
questions.explanation: Sowing discord destroys unity and is condemned (cf. Romans 16:17; Titus 3:10; James 3:16).
